svg.text: Reinforcement Learning Fundamentals
The Complete Agent-Environment Interaction Loop
Define Your Problem
What is the agent trying to accomplish?
The Agent-Environment Loop
The continuous cycle of interaction
AGENT
(Policy œÄ)
ENVIRONMENT
(The world)
Action (a)
State (s) + Reward (r)
Agent observes ‚Üí chooses action ‚Üí receives feedback ‚Üí repeat
Core Building Blocks
The fundamental concepts you need to understand

g.text: œÄ(a|s) = probability of action a in state s

svg.text: üí° Key Insight: Bellman Equation
V(s) = max [ r + Œ≥¬∑V(next state) ] ‚Äî Value of state = immediate reward + discounted future value
This recursive relationship is the foundation for all RL algorithms
Value Functions: The Goal
We want to learn how valuable states and actions are

g.text: VœÄ(s) = Expected return starting from state s, following policy œÄ
V*(s) = Best possible return from state s (optimal policy)
üí≠ "How good is it to be in this state?"
QœÄ(s,a) = Expected return from state s, taking action a, then following œÄ
Q*(s,a) = Best possible return from taking action a in state s
üí≠ "How good is it to take this action in this state?"

svg.text: Key: V(s) = maxa Q(s,a) ‚Äî The value of a state is the value of the best action you can take from it
Bellman Optimality Equations
The mathematical foundation for finding the optimal policy
Core Idea: The optimal value of a state equals the maximum expected return
you can get by choosing the best action and following the optimal policy thereafter
üí≠ Example Question:
"What's the maximum total reward I can get
starting from the kitchen, if I play optimally
from here onward?"

g.text: Q*(s,a) = R(s,a) + Œ≥ Œ£ P(s'|s,a) ¬∑ max Q*(s',a')
‚Ä¢ Value of action a in state s
‚Ä¢ + best future value from next state

svg.text: üí≠ Example Question:
"If I'm in the kitchen and I specifically choose to
'move left', what's the maximum total reward I
can get from that action onward?"
üîë Key Relationships
V*(s) = maxa Q*(s,a) ‚Äî and ‚Äî œÄ*(s) = argmaxa Q*(s,a)
The optimal policy œÄ* simply picks the action with the highest Q* value in each state
‚Ä¢ Œ≥ ‚àës' P(s'|s,a)¬∑V*(s') = discounted expected value of all possible next states
üéØ These equations define the optimal solution ‚Äî RL algorithms try to solve them
Model-based methods (know P and R) can solve directly ‚Ä¢ Model-free methods (Q-Learning, SARSA) learn from experience
